comment.author: 82862615@N00
comment._content: Francisco "Pancho" Villa (June 5, 1877 – July 23, 1923), famed Mexican revolutionary and guerrilla leader. A cropped version of this image is used on the cover of A & E's Biography DVD, Pancho Villa: Outlaw Hero. Notice that he signed this like a promotional picture. Not surprising, since he was quite media-savvy for his day, having starred as himself in a movie which helped propel him into legend.

comment.author: 23652623@N04
comment._content: Même tenue que la photo avec Braniff, Orozco et Garibaldi. comment.author: 29877325@N07
comment._content: Francisco Villa, or Mexican revolution General Francisco (" Pancho") Villa, better known as "El Centauro del Norte" (The Northern Centaur), fought  along with Emiliano Zapata during a painful Mexican revolution. Among other things, and jokes, he became a legend for his people. Gral. Pancho Viilla, however, was chased  into Mexico by  US Army General "Blackjack" Pershing, when Gral. Villa entered US territory. Villa, was known to be liked and feared by his peers, some say for hasty decisions among other anecdotes. Gral. Villa loved his Stetson hat.  This is a great photo of General Villa !!! Mexican Revolutionaries often raided Mexican military trains and captured their weapons. The 30-30 US Winchester and the German Mausser were weapons used by warring parties throughout the Mexican Revolution, which targeted rich landowners, corrupt politians and illiterate peasants seeking agrarian reforrms. Kaiser''s Germany's  presence in Mexico with obvious hostile intentions was reported.

comment.author: 62498226@N00
comment._content: He's the reason my grandfather came to the USA at 14. His father, Catarino Ordaz, told him, "That Pancho Villa, he ain't nothing but a horsethief! You may as well go live in America. I hear it's nice there too. Why don't you go and see, son, before he puts you in his loco army." It became a source of a funny story in our ancestry, which nonetheless never redeemed the feelings of loss and longing. "Mexico Lindo y Querido" makes us all weep here, because of grandpa.

comment._content: Villa was also known as "El Centauro del Norte", "The Northern Centaur", since he was born in one of the northen Mexican states, and he was fond to sport an American Stetson hat, ha,ha,ha. Villa was chased by US Cavalry General "Blackjack" Pershing into Mexico, when he entered US soil in a hostile fashion.

comment.author: 13703469@N00
comment._content:
Not a bad shot of Villa in black and white taken on a glass negative.
I like the background of Villa's men and probably captured supplies, although the light is flat a result of shooting with an overhead sun on one hot and arid day in the life of Pancho Villa. The ammo on Villa's chest is another good touch, all threatening and macho in  this gritty posed portrait of the fierce Robin Hood. Viva Zapata!

Te invito a que seas parte de la historia y no destruyas la realidad con tu ignorancia. Te recomiendo libros de historia (que no sean mexicanos) para que sepas la realidad de la cual demuestras gran ignorancia. Francisco Villa fue un defensor de los pobres y gran revolucionario. Un héroe del cual no gozan muchos en otros países. La cultura mexicana tiene muchos héroes, así como muchos asesinos. Pero te equivocas con este personaje (existen muchos documentos no gubernamentales donde demuestran lo fuera de serie que fue Pancho Villa). Tomaré tu ignorancia como parte de una generación que critica solo por tener boca y cuyas palabras no pasan a través del cerebro, sino del intestino grueso,en donde guardas el excremento. Por favor, cuando tus palabras sucumben hacia afuera, que sean coordinadas por parte de las neuronas y no de la parte fecal. Ojalá seas, te repito, parte de la historia y no destrozes con tu ignorancia nuestros símbolos.

comment.author: 29877325@N07
comment._content: Wait a minute, for some he was a bandit, for many historians he was a guerrilla leader that fought as he could the opression in Mexico; "El Centarurol Del Norte". Different culture and very different social problems at the beginning of the 20 century, General Francisco Villa or Pancho Villa, is he synonym of people's General (no Communism involved), struggling with simple and opressed people against corrupted government military and officials, and oppressive landowners.

comment.author: 29877325@N07
comment._content: You can ignore history, with our modern criteria. Francisco Villa (Pancho), was not an "enemy"of  the USA, although Gral. Pershing chased his "taiil", for entering US territory. He was basically a humble man, that fought against the oligarchy of his own country, Mexico. He was not a drug trafficker, nor a "coyote", or a "weekend drug user", but a man that demanded a fair treatment to landless, abused peasants. I advise you to go back to history lessons, bud!!! By the way, all these people gave their lives was for their own people.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
If this picture matches with Orozco, Braniff, Villa, Garibaldi, the date must be May 9th, when Braniff was on negotiations (representing goberment) with revolutionists while Ciudad Juárez was attacked (it eventually was taken on May 10th).
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 55111611@N06
comment._content: viva villa!

comment.author: 29493863@N06
comment._content: Cool pic!!

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
By May 9th was during the Juárez siege one day before the city was taken by Madero's rebels.  So this date is more likely than 29th.  By then Díaz had resigned.  The "Tratados de Ciudad Juárez" were signed on May 21rst.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
The heavy shelling began on May 8th, 1911 (as an initiative of Pascual Orozco and Francisco Villa, disoveying orders from Madero, who was trying to reach an agreement with peace envoys that reluctantly refused Diaz outsit), the city eventually fell in isurrectos hands on May 10th. with the surrender of federal defender Gen. Juan N. Navarro.  This photo closely links to picture call nr LC-B2-2227-2, in which can be seen Oscar Braniff, one of the
President Diaz peace envoys, with Orozco, Garibaldi and Villa, who wears the same clothes
chest-crossed cananas.  Behind people there´s the same hut in both pictures.
Dr. Roberto Duarte
